Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Open Data: Graduate Training for Data Sharing and Reuse in E-Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports a new graduate training program in open data sharing and data reuse in e-science at the University of Michigan. The purpose of this program is to generate new policies, practices, and technologies for data sharing that will accelerate the pace of scientific discovery and the transfer of scientific knowledge into useful products and technologies. It will build on computer science and information science research that identifies basic principles for acquiring, managing, sharing, and archiving data and for developing new tools and technologies to put these principles into practice in bioinformatics and materials research. The program will train a cohort of doctoral students in a new way of thinking about open data. These students will be capable of contributing high quality data to repositories and effectively leveraging large volumes of data in scientific research. Students from Michigan's doctoral programs in Bioinformatics, Materials Science, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and Information will be selected as IGERT trainees. The trainees will participate in a new graduate course in data curation, a multi-disciplinary public seminar series with expert speakers, and short workshops. Program faculty will also develop a supplemental summer program for undergraduates to attract diverse students and strengthen the program's impact in other scientific fields. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Open Data IGERT trained PhD students in information science, computer science, bioinformatics, and materials science to manage research data efficiently and effectively, enhancing their degrees in their chosen field or discipline.  The program preceded new data management planning requirements by the National Science Foundation, and thus provided a cohort of young scholars with a jump start on integrating good data management practices with the design of research projects, the analysis of large and complex data sets, and the ethical conduct of research.  Through a speaker series and regular workshops, the students engaged in joint problem solving across disciplinary boundaries. They developed, tested, and shared data management tools and techniques, some of which were developed to solve a problem in a specific field or laboratory but were deemed more broadly applicable.  The program produced young leaders who recognize the importance and value of managing and sharing their research data, not only to comply with requirements and guidelines, but to increase the quality and transparency of scientific research.  Openness and transparency in scientific research are important issues with public policy implications.  This project has demonstrated that, while challenges do exist, the barriers to open data sharing are not insurmountable.  

The Open Data IGERT influenced the development of a major Data Science Initiative at the University of Michigan, which was launched in September 2015. Several of the Open Data co-PIs and faculty advisors are now leaders of the Michigan Institute for Data Science (MiDAS), with Brian Athey serving as co-Director. Margaret Hedstrom, H.V. Jagadish, and Atul Prakash have served or are serving on the Management Committee and Faculty Recruitment Committee.
